awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Dark Matter Identification with Cosmic-Ray Antideuterons
awd_abstract_narration:
The nature of dark matter is currently unknown. Cosmic rays, which are energetic sub-atomic particles from space that travel at velocities near the speed of light, can help to identify dark matter particles. This is because one possible cosmic ray production mechanism is the annihilation of dark matter particles.  Cosmic ray antideuteron particles are a particularly interesting potential signature of dark matter annihilation.  This CAREER award supports scientists at the University of Hawaii to study dark matter by performing the first measurements of the cosmic-ray antideuteron flux.  The group will utilize data from the Alpha Magnetic Spectrometer (AMS), currently operating onboard the International Space Station, and data from the General Antiparticle Spectrometer (GAPS), a balloon experiment that is under development.  This award will support scientific investigations that utilize the complementary capabilities of both experiments to perform high-sensitivity measurements of cosmic-ray antideuterons.  The group is also developing a summer course to teach computer programming to local high school students.  Students will be taught programming skills using Raspberry Pi computers.  Mimicking scientific ballooning operations, the devices will be mounted on kites to measure temperatures and humidity, and take aerial pictures.
 
The planned program includes the development of antideuteron production physics simulations, analysis of AMS data, simulations and calibration of the GAPS detectors, and ultimately analysis of GAPS data.  These experiments use different technologies to detect cosmic rays.  Utilizing both provides the group with complementary data, extending the energy range of the proposed study and improving the control of the systematic effects that limit the sensitivity of the search for these rare events.  This award is jointly funded by the Physics Division and the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

por.por_cntn:
The research goal of this award was to perform the search for cosmic antideuterons to identify the nature of dark matter and other new physics by using the operational AMS-02 experiment on the International Space Station and developing the next-generation balloon experiment GAPS. Dark matter is an unidentified form of matter that is not visible in the way, e.g., stars are, but is a critical component to understand the structure of Galaxies and our Universe. Antideuterons are a particular form of antimatter, composed of one antiproton and one antineutron (the antiparticles to protons and neutrons, respectively). The advantage of using low-energy antideuterons over other channels to identify dark matter is that they are essentially free of background, making this a "smoking gun" search for dark matter. The main challenge of antideuteron searches is that their flux is predicted to be very small compared to other cosmic-ray species, resulting in the need for large experiments with long exposure times.

The research team addressed many essential aspects of the search for cosmic antideuterons during the award period. On the more theoretical or modeling side, existing antideuteron simulation models for production and interaction were tested, improved, and validated. For instance, substantial computing power on the order of more than 1,000 years was invested in developing a better model for the formation of antideuterons and heavier antinuclei. Furthermore, large-scale interaction simulations of charged particles with the geomagnetic field and Earth's atmosphere were conducted. These studies are crucial for the understanding and interpretation of the measurements with the actual experiments.

Based on the first six years of AMS-02 data, a detailed analysis of low-energy antiprotons and antideuterons was conducted. This work entails using all the available AMS-02 subsystems and performing significant simulation and data analysis studies to clearly identify antideuterons compared to any other particle and antiparticle species. As a result, the investigations provided the best available antideuteron flux limit.

Furthermore, the award facilitated the development of the next-generation low-energy antinuclei experiment GAPS, scheduled for high-altitude long-duration balloon flights from Antarctica. GAPS was in the proposal phase when this award started and is now preparing for its first flight. The work focused on simulation and analysis framework development.

The award also facilitated the 2nd Cosmic-ray Antideuteron Workshop in 2019, which furthered the exchange and collaboration between international experts in the field from both the theoretical and experimental communities.

The nature of particle astrophysics is that all of these research aspects are long-term efforts. The efforts mentioned above continue with either additional NSF or NASA funding.

The award also enabled establishing an outreach program for high school students with underrepresented-minority and economically disadvantaged backgrounds. In this annual week-long course, the students were immersed in campus life. They learned more about computer programming in natural sciences hands-on, visited different research labs, and attended regular lectures. The program has a strong track record of former participants going to college and choosing STEM majors.
